Your full name: Mrs. J. C. Johnson

Present Address: 1207 Bird St., Saskatoon, Sask.

Pioneer Address: Curzon, Sask.

Year you came to Saskatchewan: 1902

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? How many of these were bachelor's homes?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? It was mostly casual visits when you found it convenient to go.

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? Mostly on Sunday.

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? You can say everyone was glad to see each other in those days.

What time of the day did you go, - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? Always in the afternoon so we could get home again before dark.

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? Not in the very early days; most people had enough to do to provide for themselves.

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (that is, was the term to "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?) Yes, take potluck was often used if you didn't stop for dinner.

Did there ever be a "pot luck" and some bread & butter if that was all you had? Or if the folks thought that meant too much?

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "dropped in"?

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"? Everyone went, but children were very scarce prior to 1909.

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? No, but people were always ready to pitch in a helping hand when needed.

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whisky drives or dances in homes? Describe. From 1907 up to 1909 there weren't, there was not the room for parties, as the shacks were too small and people so scarce, you did well to see one another now and again for a friendly chat.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates. From 1915 after we got the telephones came in which made it easier to arrange social events.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, - every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.? We had lots of surprise parties at our home and we had the music for them. There were several places where we had bridge parties & dancing too which made one think we were coming back to civilization.
2. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials, and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, picnics, etc., if you have not described these on the School Questionnaire). Give dates.

Our school in our village was near our present village of Zelma and most social events were held there although we had our school picnic at the end of the term when they usually got to take a vacation where they had races, games, skating in the winter, etc.

There were few dances in the school or school yard but between 1915-1920 how much of your social life was centred around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

Every year had our annual Christmas. We could not forget that the children got up the programme along with the teacher, and sometimes came out in the community when it was dismissed.

The old times as well as the community hall built in 1910 a hall was built and used as a school and gymnasium. Special events were the opening of the school.

What material was it made of? How large was it?

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.?

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall?

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and came to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.)?

After we got a hall, most social events were held there, but all the schools in the surrounding district would have their annual Christmas and sometimes a dance and always a school picnic for the district after the school term ended.

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend? Went in groups, loud, pool tables to help but there weren't many babies.

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties? There was no shelter inside the hall.

11. What card games were popular in the early days? Almost every game but the most popular games were Bridge and Whist.

Was there card playing for a prize?

What dances were popular? Quadrilles, quadrille, 2, 3, 4, 7, steps, schottisches, jivey polka, everything nearly ever.

Was there any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain. No, they were very co-operative and there was a very friendly spirit among the people.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain. No, I don't think everyone seemed to attend very well and enjoy a good social evening out together and they were close to the bar, but you would hardly ever smell liquor at a dance. Men had great respect for women in those days!
12. What attempts at formality or "wants" do you remember in small towns, such as getting a bath when calling, calling cards, visitors treated ceremonially in parlor, etc.? These were some of that.

13. Was the chivalry known in your community? If so, how was most noticeable?

14. Describe any other details of chivalry, parties, etc., that you remember.

Give the date and reason for it being organized.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers' local in your community? Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it all.

How many women belonged? How often did it meet?

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? When was it organized? Approximately how many women belonged to it? Describe what you remember of its activities and services.

In all the years since kinds of bands, the newly founded Red Cross and different organizations, the children's clinics, the children's home and all a great value to the community.

When was it organized?

Approximately how many women belonged to it?

Describe what you remember of its activities and services.

In all the years since I have lived in this community, I have never seen a land surveyor's crew working on the property. It seems like a very long time ago.

Red Cross and different organizations helped people during the Depression. The Red Cross provided food and clothing to children who needed it.

There was a bridge over the river near our home.
21. What games did boys play in summer (marbles, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)?

Well, we played a variety of games. We played football and often joined in the games.

What games did girls play in summer (skipping rope, play house, etc.)?

Boys played football, while girls played playing house.
